adeaguayo.bio: Anna de Aguayo has been teaching at Dawson College since 2002. She holds a B.A. (Anthropology) from the University of Toronto and a M.Sc. (Economics) from the University of London. She is at the dissertation stage of a Ph.D. (Anthropology) from the University of Toronto. Anna’s fieldwork includes a study of economic development in Sumatra, Indonesia, First Nations self-government in British Columbia, and berry pickers and border crossings in New Brunswick. Anna teaches Introduction to Anthropology, Amerindians, Anthropology of Sexuality, Research Methods, Quantitative Methods, and Integrative Seminar (Fast Food Nation). She is associated with the Child Studies and Women’s Studies profiles. Anna also maintains the Anthropology in Film website and heads the Dawson Odd Objects Detectives.

agrassi.bio: Antonietta Grassi has been teaching at Dawson in the visual arts department since 1998. She holds a degree in Design from Ryerson University in Toronto, a B.F.A from Concordia University in Montreal, and an M.F.A from L’Universite du Québec a Montreal. She has had numerous solo and group exhibitions across Canada, Italy, and Europe. She has participated in notable shows on contemporary abstract painting such as Peinture Peinture (organized by Rene Blouin in Montreal), Peintures de genres:  L’actualité de la peinture abstraite au Quebec in Lyon, France, Hommage to Yves Gaucher at the Leonard and Bina Ellen Art Gallery in Montreal, and more recently, L’Abstraction: une maniere de voir, at the Musée du Québec. Her major exhibitions include the Scar Calendar (1996-1998), Painting Dot Com (1998- 2000), Babble (2000- 2003), and Mots Perdus (2003- 2006). She is the recipient of numerous grants such as the Canada Council for the Arts and the Conseil des Arts et Lettres du Quebec.  Her work can be found in numerous public and private collections, including the Musée du Québec.

amanniste.bio:
Educated as a painter and printmaker, Andres Manniste has been teaching since 1974.

He has participated in many exhibitions and has received several important prizes.

His work can be found in the Montreal Museum of Contemporary Art, Rhizome artbase, at the New Museum in New York, the Heritage Collection of the Quebec Archives, the Government of Ontario Art Collection and the Canada Council Art Bank.

bfrumkin.bio: Beverly Frumkin is an Art Historian, in the Department of Fine Arts, Dawson College.  She holds both a B.A. and M.A. (Fine Arts) from McGill University with a  B.F.A. at Concordia University.She currently teaches art history in all areas with special interests in photographic criticism. She is an attested docent at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts and lectures frequently to many community organizations.

bhirji.bio: I am specifically interested in intercultural and interfaith issues. My specializations are Old and New Testament Theology, Qur’anic Exegesis and Medeival Islamic Philosophy. The courses I usually teach are: Sacred Writings, Judaism, Christianity and Islam, Personal experience of the Holy, Intergrative Seminar, Research Methods. My teaching approach is interactive, so that each student feels comfortable expressing her/his view in the classroom. Students are encouraged to explore their own interests within the confines of the course. Besides lectures, audio-visual presentations and some field experiences, form the basis of the teaching methodology.

sectors: Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering

Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering

bmarcy.bio:
Bob Marcy has taught both Black & White and Color laboratory skills for 22 years. In the last few years he began transferring his knowledge and long time fascination with computers to the digital side of photography. While teaching basic Photoshop skills to students, he now shoots exclusively with a digital SLR.

Not willing to abandon the past, Bob has also taught extensively about early historical photo processes such as Cyanotype, Van Dyke Brown and Salt Paper printing, photo techniques which were the "cutting edge" of technology in the 1800's and continues to teach Polaroid Transfer and SX-70 Manipulation to his students.

Aside from his teaching, Bob is a former chairman of the department and he co-ordinates the Student/Graduate email list which keeps both current and former students informed of upcoming events and job offers that are received by the Photography Program. In his spare time, he builds/modifies computers from spare parts and troubleshoots the problems that, invariably, arise.

carseneault.bio: Claude Arseneault has a BA and MA from McGill and has taught at Dawson for over 20 years. A printmaker by training Claude, has had an extensive exhibition record participating  in group shows related to printmaking in Canada and the USA. Her most recent shows include Gravures en liberté (2007) ,Un Conte (2006), and Partie liée (2006). A member of GRAFF ,she is also president of ARPRIM(Conseil d`administration du regroupement pour la promotion de l`art imprimé).

caudet.bio:
After obtaining her diploma in Social Sciences, Chantal  Audet moved from the Eastern Townships to Montreal to study Graphic Design at  Dawson College. Upon graduation in 1988, she was hired by Rolf Harder &  Associates. She worked as Harder’s assistant for five years on many projects  for clients such as Canada Post, Hoffman Laroche, and Consolidated Bathurst.  The influence of Rolf Harder, a member of AGI, was fundamental in shaping her  approach to design.

From designing full-time, she went on to teaching parttime,  freelancing, and raising a family. While teaching pre-press procedures in her  hometown and then for the Marie-Victorin School Board, Chantal obtained a  certificate in education from l’Université de Sherbrooke. To keep active as a  designer, she worked on many projects, some involving the development of  educational and art-therapy tools for the Marie-Enfant Hospital now attached to  Ste-Justine Hospital, and others.

She has designed over thirty corporate identities over the  last twenty years. In 2000 she became a member of the graphic design faculty at  Dawson College. Aside from her full-time teaching at Dawson, she is currently  working on branding a new line of fine chocolate, constructing her own house  and doing research in the history of visual communication.

chastings.bio: Clifford Hastings has been schooled in the field of human geography and has recently taught the Introduction to Geography, the Geography of Montreal and the Environmental Problems and Challenges courses in addition to the Social Science Program’s Research Methods, Quantitative Methods and Integrative Seminar courses. He holds a B.A. (Anthropology) and M.A. (Geography) from McGill University. He has been the coordinator for the Social Science’s International Business Studies Profile here at Dawson College. He is also a member of the Canadian Association of Geographers.

chowell.bio: Cornelia Howell joined Dawson College in 1998. She holds a Minor in Russian Studies (Université de Montréal), a B.A. in Anthropology (Concordia University) and a M.Sc. in Anthropology (Université de Montréal). For her fieldwork, she studied parenthood through adoption in Montréal. Cornelia teaches Introduction to Anthropology, Medical Anthropology, The Anthropology of Parenthood, and Race and Racism. Cornelia is associated with the Child Studies profile.

cwhittaker.bio: Chris Whittaker went to Heritage College (Cegep) in Hull Quebec and then   studied Engineering Physics at Queen’s University (B.Sc. 1989, M.Sc.   1992). As an undergraduate he specialized in aeronautical and nuclear   engineering and for his masters degree he studied how the apparent   viscosity of nematic liquid crystals changes in electric and magnetic   fields. Chris also holds a Master’s degree in Social Work from the   University of Toronto (1996) and he has prepared two radio documentaries   for the CBC program Ideas – including one about physics called “Size   Matters” which originally aired in October 2002.
positions: Program Coordinator of First Choice Science

dberry.bio: D. Shawn Berry, (M.A. Concordia), has been a teacher at Dawson College since 1995. He has taught a variety of courses including introductory sociology, sociology of work, culture and media, social problems, and social deviance. His main research interests are in the fields of mass media and deviance. Professor Berry received an M.A. in Sociology from Concordia University and an M.A. in Journalism from The University of Western Ontario.

sectors: Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering
Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering
Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering

dcorman.bio: Don Corman has an MFA from the Nova Scotia College of Art and Design and currently teaches in the Professional Photography Department at Dawson College.His creative work is represented in many collections, including the Canadian Museum of Contemporary Photography, University of Lethbridge, Italian Embassy, Nickle Arts Museum and the Canada Council Art Bank. He has exhibited his work extensively in Canada with solo exhibitions at the Art Gallery of Hamilton, Vancouver Art Gallery, Dazibao, Nickle Arts Museum and the Dunlop Art Gallery. He was the co-founder of the Stride Gallery in Calgary and is the author of Digit and Comfort and Cleanliness, two published books of his artwork. He has received numerous awards and grants, including a Canada Council B Grant and a Quebec A Grant and the Toronto Art Directors Merit Award .His recent design work has included projects for the Financial Post, Ericsson Communications, CRB Foundation and the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts. His photographic work will be included in a new book on the history of contemporary Canadian photography to be published in 2003.

sectors: Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering

Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering

dhopkins.bio:
David Hopkins, chair of the department, is an award winning photographer and the recipient of the Director General's Teaching Excellence Award for l995-96 . He specializes in black & white documentary photography but also teaches across the curriculum from studio classes to computer imaging. In addition to being an active photographer, David occasionally contributes articles to a variety of magazines here in Canada and abroad.

David believes in experimentation and play as powerful learning tools in his courses.His personal photographic explorations (read “creative distractions”) include digital imaging, 3D and pinhole photography, and shooting B&W panoramic landscapes using disposable cameras.

sectors: Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering
Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering

dloomer.bio: Dan Loomer, (M.A. McGill University), has taught a number of courses at Dawson, including Sociology of Law and Individual and Society. He has also taught courses for the Community Leadership and Recreation Training Program. His current research interest is in the field of social deviance.

dmuhlstock.bio: David Muhlstock, (M.A. McMaster), has taught courses about the family and the educational system in Canada, and he recieved an award for teaching excellence because of his work at Dawson. Professor Muhlstock has recently done research on social change in Eastern Europe and is interested as well in the sociology of education.

dnaggiar.bio:
Didier Naggiar has been teaching at Dawson College for over  20 years. He also teaches in the Professional Photography Department. He has a  Diplôme d’Université en Sciences et Techniques de l’Expression et de la  Communication from the University of Censier (Paris III, France) and is a  graduate of the Dawson Institute of Photography (1979).

Established in Montreal since 1982, Didier has been working  for a variety of magazines and corporations, specializing in product  illustration, architecture and corporate photography. For the past several  years he has been extensively upgrading his skills in digital photography and  computing. When not “glued” to his computer, Didier likes traveling and filling  his brain with new images.

dshea.bio:
(MA. History, Concordia University)

Areas of specialization: South Asian history, women’s history, North-South history

dweeks.bio:
David graduated from the Ontario College of Art in Toronto with a Diploma in Industrial Design in 1991. He apprenticed in Olivetti's Centro Stile in Milan, Italy from 1991 to 1992.

Upon returning to Canada, he moved to Montreal where he worked at a design consulting firm from 1994 to 1996. At that point he began his own business in industrial design. He first taught in the Industrial Design department in 1998, after which he returned to Dawson in 2002 and managed the department's workshops for five years.  He has been a full-time member of the Industrial Design department's faculty from 2008 to the present.

elinn.bio: Elizabeth Linn has been with Dawson College since 1986. She has a B.A. (Latin American Studies) and a M.A. (Anthropology) from McGill University. Elizabeth has done fieldwork with Aymará alpaca herders in the Andes of Peru. She teaches Introduction to Anthropology, Race and Racism, Advanced Topics in Anthropology, and Integrative Seminar. She is associated with the Child Studies profile. Elizabeth is responsible for placing Child Studies students in fieldwork and volunteer work for their Integrative Seminar, mainly at the Montreal Children’s Hospital and, beginning this year, at the Covered Garden, a YMCA program for newly arrived refugees.

fmartin.bio:
After obtaining his Bachelor’s degree in Graphic Design from  l’Université du Québec à Montréal in 1993, François began working at Paprika as  a freelancer and subsequently joined Gottschalk+Ash International as a senior  designer for four years. In 1998, he founded Fugazi inc., a design studio where  both partners work as consultants in visual communication, mainly with  corporate and cultural institutions.

His work includes designing books, exhibition catalogues, as  well as developing visual identities and printed corporate communications.  François devotes his talent to the development and application of a graphic  language that is adapted to a prestigious clientele. In addition, he teaches  several courses to emerging designers at Dawson College.

fmulvey.bio: Frank Mulvey is a full time teacher who has taught at Dawson since 1989.  He holds both BFA and MFA degrees from Concordia University, and has had fourteen solo shows featuring his paintings and drawings.  The publication The Stillness of Time – Drawings by Frank Mulvey can be found in Dawson’s library collection.  Frank teaches a range of courses at Dawson that involve design, drawing, painting, collage and the photographic medium.  Below is one of Frank’s charcoal drawings entitled From Another Garden (size 29 x 24 3/8 inches).

positions: Director of Information Systems & Technology and Corporate Affairs

galbanese.bio:
(MA. History, Concordia University)

Areas of specialization: Canadian history, Quebec history, economic history, immigration history

gaszalos.bio:
Graduated the Fine Arts University of Bucharest in 1975 and holds a Bachelor Degree in Industrial Design. He worked for 15 years in Research and Development for public transportation in Bucharest.

Moved to Montreal in1988 and has been involved as a free-lance designer in the development of consumer products, medical equipment, toys and industrial machinery.

Gheza Aszalos has been teaching Industrial Design at Dawson College since 1998.

ggefin.bio:
Gyula Gefin is principal of Gefin Design, a studio based in  Montreal that offers creative services in all aspects of graphic design. In  1982, after graduating in Graphic Design from Dawson College, Gyula moved to  Milan, Italy where he remained for the following 15 years. His first four years  working for Contact Studio, led by a Swiss designer, became an important period  in his professional formation. In 1987 he and two partners formed Trio Design,  a small innovative graphic design studio offering complete design services. 

In 1990 a merger with another studio led Gyula and his  partners to create Design in Progress, a multidisciplinary design studio. In  1993, continuing his career as an Art Director at Sudler & Hennessey Milano  (a division of Young & Rubicam), he soon became Creative Director of the  International Business Unit where he produced numerous award winning projects. 

Gyula returned to Montreal in 1997 and, aside from running  his design studio, he teaches several design courses at Dawson College.

hjohnson.bio: Harlan Johnson studied at Concordia University obtaining a BFA 1979 and MFA in 1995. This Nova Scotian artist has exhibited nationally and internationally since the 1980`s. Johnson`s work in painting frequently explores the intersections between scientific imaging, illustration and abstraction. His next exhibition “Puits d`Huile”, is planned for Montreal`s McLure Gallery in April of 2008.

hnadeau.bio: D.E.C. from Le Petit Séminaire de Québec, BSc. (Physics) from Université   Laval , M.Phil. and PhD.(Physics) from Yale University, postdocs at   Saclay (France), Seoul National University (Korea) and McGill. My domain   of research is the Theory of Elementary Particles. I have used bag   models and skyrmions to explain static properties of hadrons, done   calculations of probabilities of observing exotic particles at future   colliders and worked on Non-Relativistic Quantum Chromodynamics. I have   taught statics and mechanics, waves, electricity and magnetism, modern   physics, strength of materials, a bit of thermodynamics and fluid   mechanics.

jgomez.bio: Juan Gomez-Perales is a Canadian sculptor, installation and digital media artist who hails from Madrid, Spain. He earned his BFA from the University of Manitoba and MFA from Victoria. He has been in Montreal since 1988 and teaches at Dawson and Concordia University. Juan has exhibited internationally receiving numerous awards and artists grants.

jguindon.bio:
Jocelyn Guindon has taught a number of courses at Dawson in Geography (Introduction to Geography, Urban Geography, Travel and Tourism and Human Geography) and Methods courses (Research Methods, Quantitative Methods and the Integrative Seminar). He has completed undergraduate studies at the University of Ottawa in Public administration and at UQÀM in Urban Planning and a PhD at McGill University in Urban Social Geography. His dissertation focussed on urban spaces as being sexually defined and controlled.

Jocelyn Guindon is Profile Coordinator for Travel and Tourism.

jharvey.bio:
(Ph.D. History, McGill University)

Areas of specialization: Quebec history, Canadian social history

sectors: Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering

jjoos.bio:
Julianna Joos is a full-time teacher at Dawson College in the Fine Arts Department; she has been teaching here since 1998 in Printmaking, Drawing and Computer Art.

Julianna Joos has degrees from Concordia University and from Université du Québec à Montréal, respectively at the BA and the Masters levels; in 1996 she graduated with a Maîtrise ès arts (M.A.) Programme de maîtrise en arts plastiques, concentration création,.

Her professional career started more than thirty years ago; she has had numerous solo exhibitions and has participated in over one hundred group shows around the world.

Her production has evolved from a thirty year printmaking concentration to a multidisciplinary production involving printmaking, computer assisted weaving, digital imaging, and sewing. She is as comfortable in traditional processes as she is in digital technologies.

departments: AEC Accounting Principles & Related Computer Applications

jlaval.bio:
Jacques laval graduated from Université du Québec à Montreal in 1982 with a bachelor degree in Design de l’Environnement.

He has more than 20 years of experience as a consultant working with various type of manufacturers in Canada and in USA: designing communication devices, medical equipment, consumer hand tools, telephone booth, using almost all the material processes available: die casting, sand casting, aluminum extrusion injection molding, vacuum forming, structural foam, plastic extrusion…

He started in 1988 a small high-tech corporation, Secant Home Automation, designing with a team of electronic and software experts the first Canadian made home automation system. He left the corporation in 1993 going back in Industrial design consultation but not for long. In 1994 he started with an American colleague, Kurt Gauss, the Dawson College Industrial Design program.

Jacques laval has redesigned with two other industrial design school teachers the industrial design program for all the ID program in the province of Quebec. The new program was introduced at Dawson in 2001 and is now fully implemented.

lcharbonneau.bio:
A part-time lecturer at Dawson College in 1997 and 1998,  Lise joined the Graphic Design Department in 2002. She brings a broad range of  expertise acquired as creative vice-president, creative director, and artistic  director at Goodhue & Associates, a company well known for its expertise  with logos, branding, annual reports, corporate brochures, packaging,  multimedia and web design.

Goodhue was merged with the prominent agency Publicis in  2001, giving her experience with major projects in Montreal and Toronto. She  worked closely with the Montréal Museum of Fine Arts, Rona, Canada Post, Lise  Watier, CN, Fido, Laurentian Bank, Labopharm and Métro, to name a few.

Some previous experiences allowed her to reinforce her  computer skills and to give creative workshops. At SNCLavalin & Lavalin she  refined her conceptual approach by working on cultural mandates for Lavalin  Gallery, the Montréal Museum of Fine Arts, La Cinémathèque québécoise and Imax,  and on corporate projects designing logos, corporate identities, brochures and  annual reports.

Lise has been awarded in national and international  competitions. She has served as a design jury member in Toronto and as an  invited guest speaker. Her commitment has been recognized in several books,  magazines, and TV programs.

Lise has a diploma in graphic design, and studied fine arts  at the Université du Québec à Montréal. During her career, she took classes at  Collège de Maisonneuve in computer science, at CESAM in multimedia, at The  Québec Institute of Graphic Communications in business communications, at the  Saidye Bronfman Centre in drawing and painting, and recently with Seymour Segal  creative workshops. In the summer of 2008, she participated in the workshop “Le  roman graphique” offered by Lino at École international de Percé of the  Université Laval.

Her passion for traveling motivated her to study Japanese  language at McGill University. She also took part in several group art  exhibitions, and, in 2007, had a solo exhibition at the Warren Gallery of  Dawson College. She appears in “Seymour Segal: The Power of Painting,” a film  for which she is credited with original concept and participation.

sectors: Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering

ldantoni.bio: An English specialist with the Centre since 2002, Leanne is a full-time Education Advisor in the Centre, and is currently the centre's coordinator. Her responsibilities include: individual appointments/drop-ins, Preparatory Arts Labs, Paid Peer English & Group tutors, BXE tutor supervision, Exit Exam Workshops, and the CALL Program Committee.

sectors: Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering
Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering

lhlarin.bio: Lise-Hélène Larin (BFA Concordia University 1976,MFA Université du Québec a Montréal 1988,PhD in-progress Université du Québec a Montréal) teaches painting and drawing at Concordia University as well as sculpture and drawing at Dawson College. Larin is a multidisciplinary artist who creates non-figurative 3D animated films that question sculpture, painting, photography and 3D animation.Since 2002,her work was selected three times at Siggraph,an international Conference on 3D animation,and was part of a travelling show in Europe and the USA. The Sony Centre in Berlin has recently screened her films, which were also shown in Belgium and the USA. She received an award of excellence for her research in 3D animation.

sectors: Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering
Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering

lnixon.bio: Most of my teaching career has been spent at universities (in Quebec and Manitoba). I began to teach at Dawson College in 1998, where I feel very much at home. Since coming to Dawson I have been very favourably impressed by the quality of both the students and the professors. In addition to Social Science Methods courses (RM, QM and IS) and the Introduction to Religion course, I have taught: Judaism, Christianity and Islam; Western Religions and the Arts; and Religions of the East. I welcome suggestions from students as to how I can more effectively help them to learn the subject matter and the skills required in the courses I teach.

lparent.bio:
After studying Graphic Design at Concordia University and l'Université du Québec à Montréal, Luc Parent worked as designer and art director in the magazine publishing field. Later, he worked as a freelance designer for many design offices in Montreal. In 1981, he joined Jean Morin designers, AGI (Alliance graphique internationale) where he collaborated with the apanish designer Fernando Medina, AGI. He was involved in the development of corporate identities and signage system for large Canadian and Quebec Corporations.

He has been recipient of two design bursaries from the government of Quebec and was invited to be on juries for the Conseil des arts et lettres du Québec, and for Concours Grafika. In 1986-87, he worked at Total Design in Amsterdam, Netherlands. On his return to Montreal he joined Lavalin Communication and then La Direction des communications de l'Université de Montréal.

From 1988-2000 he operated his own design studio, serving cultural, institutional and corporate clients. In 1990, he began teaching at Dawson College, Collège Athunsic, Collège du Vieux-Montréal and l'École de design de l'Université du Québec à Montréal. Since 1997, Parent has been a permanent teacher at Dawson College and presently the Chairperson of the Graphic Design Department.

His work has been published in several Canadian, American and European publications. He has also been published in l'Affiche au Québec and le Design au Québec by Marc H. Choko. He has won mentions and awards at design competitions and design biennials such as Brno (Czekoslovakia), Warsaw (Poland), Lahti (Finland), the first Poster Triennal in Moscow, the New York Art Directors Club 6th International Exhibition, The Toronto International Type Symposium and Grafika, Quebec. In 2014 he is invited by the 13th International Biennial of Mexico to design a poster on the theme: Canada- Mexico, 70 years of diplomatic relations.

His work have been shown in group exhibitions in China, Buenos Aires, Brasil and at the Canadian Cultural Center in Paris, France. Some of his posters are in the permanent collection of the Plakatmuseum am Niederrhein, Germany and in the permanent collection of the Dansk Plakatmuseum, (Danish Poster Museum), Danemark.

Luc Parent is a member of the Société des designers graphiques du Québec.

positions: Coordinator of Canada/Quebec Entente Higher Education Sector

lsimms.bio: Lorraine Simms is a painter who lives and works in Montreal, Quebec. She graduated from O.C.A.D. and completed her MFA at Concordia University, where she also taught for many years. Currently she teaches in the Fine Art Department at Dawson College. She has been the recipient of numerous awards from the Canada Council and the Conseil des Arts et des lettres du Québec. Her work has been presented in solo and group exhibitions across Canada and in the U.S. Her paintings are included in many important public collections, including the Musée du Québec, the Tom Thomson Memorial Gallery and Concordia University.

mblaker.bio: Mark Blaker joined Dawson College in 1972. He holds a B.A. from Simon Fraser University (Anthropology) and a M.A. from McGill University (Anthropology). His fieldwork involved archival research in Paraguay. Mark teaches Introduction to Anthropology, Human Evolution, Peoples of the World, Third World Anthropology, and Anthropology and Critical Contemporary Issues. He is associated with the North-South Studies profile. Mark runs Intramural Basketball at Dawson and also coaches soccer outside the College. He can sometimes be spotted wearing a gorilla suit to class.

mdelbalso.bio: Michael Del Balso, (Ph.D. McGill), Coordinator, Social Science Program, has been chair of the Department of Sociology in the past and currently serves on the Senate of Dawson College. Dr. Del Balso has co-authored The Italians of Montreal and First Steps: A Guide to Social Research (with Alan Lewis). Currently Dr. Del Balso is doing research together with Michael Rosenberg on the organizational features of ethnocultural minority communities in Montreal.

mdomanski.bio: Maciek Domanski began teaching at Dawson in 2003. Maciek holds a B.A. in Sociology and Anthropology (Concordia University) and a M.Sc. in Anthropology (Université de Montréal). He also recently completed a Ph.D. in Anthropology (Université de Montréal). Maciek has done fieldwork in a refugee camp in Italy, and with ethnic and immigrant communities in Montréal and Ottawa. His research interests include discourse analysis and medieval studies. Maciek teaches Introduction to Anthropology and Research Methods, and is associated with the Child Studies profile. He enjoys, among other things, rock climbing, mountaineering, canoeing, and off-trail skiing.

Areas of specialization: Canadian history, native history, legal history, women’s history

mfarkas.bio:

mgriffin.bio:
Marjorie Griffin obtained a joint degree in Art and Design  and Education, and a Certificate of Education from Birmingham University, UK.  She worked as a teacher and designer in England, Spain and Jamaica, before  moving to Nigeria to work on a government project producing educational  publishing materials.

Following further experience in Scotland with educational  publishing, she moved to Toronto to work as a senior designer for Holt,  Rinehart and Winston. After relocating to Montreal, she began to teach at  Dawson College in 1986. She has specialized in typography, basic design and  semiotics. She has served two terms as chair of the department, and received  the Teaching Excellence Award in her final year of teaching. In 2004 she became  a founding member of Alo, the Graphic Design Alumni Association, and worked as  faculty liaison for that organization until 2010. Marjorie is currently  teaching on a part-time basis in the department. She continues to do occasional  freelance design projects, and has resumed work on a parallel interest, in  painting.

mhainaut.bio:
DEC, Community Recreation Leadership Training; Candidate for B.A. in Leisure Studies.

EXPERIENCE: Counselor, Program Director camp Weredale, Director of Kuujjuaq Youth camp (residential); International Youth Peace and Justice Tour; Youth/Recreation worker in community centers; Inner-city youth worker. CampStaff Training, Teaching music to youth; MEMBER OF:  Faculty liaison and member, CRLT Alumni; Dawson College Alumni.

PAST MEMBER OF: Curriculum revision Committee-Ministere de l' Education.

mmcintyre.bio: Educated as an art historian and artist, Maureen has been teaching at Dawson College since 1977.She was an Assistant Curator at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts, involved in research on architecture for  Quebec`s Ministry of  Cultural Affairs, creator of a Museum for the Grey Nuns of Montreal and was with the David Stewart Museum. Her publications have been on Montreal architecture. Her artwork has been in group exhibitions in Montreal and the Maritimes.

positions: Executive Director of Confucius Institute in Quebec and China Project

msantella.bio:
Graduated, with distinction, from the school of Industrial Design at Carleton University, Ottawa, in June of 1987. Gained extensive experience in plastic product design and transportation design while working as a junior and senior industrial designer at various design studios in Montreal and in France between 1985 and 1991. Founded DIBIS, Inc. in January 1992, a product design and manufacturing company based in Montreal.

Michael has received international design awards and recognition from both the industry and his peers for the quality of his products and design projects. His products have been selected by numerous publications and design exhibitions throughout North America. The Museum of Modern Art in New York City as well as numerous other well know retail shops around the world sell products designed by Michael Santella and manufactured by DIBIS. He is the only three time winner of the prestigious Accent on Design Award at the New York International Gift Fair, given annually for best product design.

Michael has also working as a free lance Industrial Designer and teaching at the University de Montreal. He has been teaching at Dawson College since August 2002.

sectors: Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering

mseguin.bio:
Graduated from Carleton University in 1987, Michel holds a bachelor’s degree in Industrial Design. He also studied in avionics at l’Ecole nationale d’aéronautique.
First worked in 1988 for an Exhibit Design firm before joining an Industrial Design consultancy from 1989 to 1992 in Montréal.

From 1993 to 1996, he was responsible for Research and Development for a major signage manufacturer. He founded Segya Designers in 1992, an Industrial Design consultancy still active today, specializing in consumer and industrial plastic products, signage and lighting design. In the fall of 1998, Michel became a faculty member of Dawson College’s Industrial Design department. He has also taught Industrial Design at l’École de design de l’Université du Québec à Montréal.

sectors: Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering
Sector: Science, Medical Studies and Engineering

mtoharia.bio:
Undergraduate in physics at the Universidad Autonoma de Madrid, MSc in 
physics at UQAM, PhD in theoretical particle physics at the University 
of California Davis, postdocs at the University of Michigan, Syracuse 
University and the University of Maryland and research associate status 
at Concordia University. My field of research is phenomenology of 
particle physics beyond the Standard Model (SM). I have worked in 
supersymmetric extensions of the SM but I am mainly interersted in 
extra-dimensional extensions of it, in particular in the so-called 
Randall-Sundrum scenarios where one highly warped extra dimension is 
added to our usual 3+1 spacetime. Currently, I work on Higgs 
phenomenology in this context.

http://www.researchgate.net/profile/Manuel_Toharia

I teach physics courses of the cegep curriculum, my favorite one being 
waves and modern physics.

ndahan.bio: After completing studies in Pure & Applied Science, Nelly worked towards a degree at the McGill School of Architecture. She subsequently worked for Michael Mills Productions, an award winning animation/live-action commercial film studio, in various creative capacities for many years. After graduating from Commercial Photography at Dawson College, and working in the medium, photography became her first love. She has enjoyed sharing it over a long teaching career in the Graphic Design and Professional Photography departments.

ngabrilopoulos.bio: Nick Gabrilopoulos began teaching at Dawson College in 2002. His degrees include a B.Sc. (Mathematics and Computer Science) and a B.A. (Anthropology) from McGill University, and a M.A. (Archaeology) and Ph.D. (dissertation in progress) from the University of Calgary. Nick has engaged in archaeological excavations at the Historic Bar-U Ranch in Alberta and in Chihuahua, Mexico. He also has done anthropological fieldwork, studying traditional housing of the Tallensi of Ghana in West Africa. He teaches Introduction to Anthropology, Research Methods, Quantitative Methods and Integrative Seminar (Globalization). Nick also is associated with the Commerce and Child Studies profiles.

nlondon.bio: Naomi London has been a part-time faculty member in the Fine Arts Department at Dawson College since 2000. She is also a visual artist with a practice focused on sculpture/performance/drawing.* Her works can be seen in several public collections including the Musée d’art contemporain de Montréal. She has an MFA from the University of Southern California (USC) and a BFA from Concordia University, Montréal.

pduarte.bio: I have always straddled the arts/science "divide". My initial Cegep   education was in the arts, specifically Photography and Cinematography   (Vanier College, 1979), later I studied Science (Dawson College 1984,   B.Sc. Physics McGill University 1988, M.Sc. in Physics Concordia   University 1992). My graduate studies were in the area of Mathematical   Physics applied to the atomic physics domain, studying novel approaches   to solving Shroedinger's equation. I also studied Computer Science   (diploma in computer science from Concordia University, 2000). I've   worked as a teacher for the last ten years at various institutions. But   during the same period and previous to it I also worked in the area of   atmospheric physics at the McGill weather Observatory, biomechanics   (Diagnospine), and computer science (Discreet). What really turns me on   at the moment is music and photography, that is, both trying to make   music and the physics of music and images. I'm also interested in   research into physics education; and in the relationship between   philosophy and physics.

ranctil.bio:
Born in the Eastern Townships, Rock Anctil studied graphic  design at Collège de Sherbrooke and graduated with a DEC in 1981. He worked  freelance then majored in Graphic Design at the Université du Québec à  Montréal, graduating in 1985.

He worked for various design offices in Montreal. He and  Carina Marinelli created Marinelli+Anctil Art & Design in 1987. The studio  has a large variety of clients and has won several awards in Québec, Canada and  abroad. Their works have appeared in design publications here, in the USA,  Europe and Asia.

Parallel to his practice, he taught graphic design and  typography at Collège de Sherbrooke from 1987 to 2000. He also taught  typography at Concordia University. He was the co-author of the new graphic  design program for Collège de Sherbrooke. Rock Anctil now teaches full time in  the Graphic Design Department at Dawson College in Montreal.

As a member of the Société des designers graphiques du  Québec (SDGQ), he collaborated in the publication of the book Devenir designer  graphique. He previously wrote and lectured about typography and legibility in  exhibit design contexts.

Why teaching? “This is the best way to keep learning all the  time!”

rkearney.bio:
Ronan Kearney studied Fine Arts at the National College of  Art in Dublin, Ireland and is a graduate cum laude in Graphic and Typographic  Design from the Koninklijke Academic Van Beeldende Kunsten (Royal Academy of  Art), The Hague, Holland. He has worked as a graphic designer in Ireland,  Canada and the United States 

He worked for Corporation ARC in Montreal from 1974 to 1981  and was involved in the design of corporate identities of such companies as VIA  Rail Canada, the CN Tower and Maritime Marine. He also worked as a senior  graphic designer for Environmental Programs Inc. in Baltimore and New York.

Since 1981 he has been the principal of Signa Design  Communications Inc. in Montreal. He is the recipient of design awards from such  professional bodies as the New York Art Director’s Club and la Société des  designers graphiques du Québec.

He has been a faculty member of the graphic design  department of Dawson College since 1991 and is a past Chairman of that  department. He is married, collects toy soldiers and has two cats.

rsegarajasinghe.bio: An ESL and learning disabilities specialist and educator, Rashmini joined the Centre in Winter 2008 as a full-time Education Advisor after working in the United States and China. Her responsibilities include: individual appointments/drop-ins, BXE Peer Teaching, Preparatory English Labs coordination, Summer School Coordination, evaluation and follow-up of students with learning disabilities, Writing English Lab, BXE tutor coordination, Exit Exam and Pronunciation Workshops.

rvandusen.bio: Ray VanDusen has been actively involved in many aspects of photography for over 30 years. As a fine art photographer with an MFA degree, Ray has exhibited in numerous exhibitions here in NorthAmerica as well as Europe. He has been awarded many grants for hiswork (eg. Canada Council, Ontario Arts Council, etc.), pieces of which are held in a number of public and private collections (eg.National Gallery of Canada, Canadian Museum of Contemporary Photography, etc.). In his commercial photography role, he has photographed for the gamut of industry from banks to airlines to hotels and large manufacturers (eg. Royal Bank, American Airlines, Sheraton Hotels, Bombardier, etc.). Ray has been teaching at Dawson College since 1979 where he specializes in digital imaging, compositional design as well as the creative process. Ray has also been teaching digital imaging at the Maine Photographic Workshops for the past ten years.

scote.bio:
Upon completion of her bachelor’s degree in graphic design  l’Université du Québec à Montréal in 1985, Suzanne studied under Mieczyslaw  Gorowski at the Academy of Fine Arts in Krakow. Back in Canada, she worked for  firms in Montréal and Toronto, as Artistic Director at both Graphème and  Goodhue & Associates.

Suzanne then co-founded l’Atelier du Presse-citron, a  boutique firm, in 1995. The design studio specializes in exhibition and package  design, creating award-winning work for clients such as The Canadian Museum of  Civilization, The Bata Shoe Museum, Fruits & Passion and many others.  Suzanne has recently started teaching package design to emerging designers at  Dawson College.

Since 1988, she received numerous awards notably from The  Art Directors Club of New-York, Art Directors Club of Toronto, Graphisme  Québec, The Package Design Council International, Studio Magazine Awards,  Applied Arts Awards, Grafika, Communication Arts, How magazine, Gilbert Papers,  Art 2000/Royal Canadian Academy of Arts, Les prix de la créativité Domtar and  Design Inspiration Awards/Fraser Papers.

spompey.bio:
B.A. Economics Concordia University 1990

EXPERIENCE: Community Organizer /Animation Director Comité Jeunesse N.D.G. Animateur Ville de Montréal 1990-1996. First Tee of America Level I Teaching Instructor. Teacher in Community Recreational Leadership Training at Dawson College. Recreational Activities Technician English Montreal School Board. Head basketball coach at Marymount Academy. Head Coach Dawson College. Sports Activities Coordinator for day camps for the borough of N.D.G./C.D.N. Time Management, 1st Aid and CPR training. Table de Concertation Jeunesse. Table concertation 6-12.

MEMBER OF: Member of the Board for Comité Jeunesse N.D.G. Summer Day Camp Committee for the borough of N.D.G./C.D.N. Police Advisory Committee of Station 11, United Sports Council, N.D.G./C.D.N. Basketball Committee, Jeux de Montréal Committee.

sscott.bio: Susan Scott was educated in England, completing her Dip. Ad in Graphic Design at the Central School of Art and design in London. At her graduate show, she was invited by Colin Forbes to join Crosby, Fletcher, Forbes (now Pentagram) as a junior designer. Emigrating to Canada in 1970, she worked as a book designer at McCelland and Stewart in Toronto. In 1972, she moved to Montreal and worked at Gottschalk+Ash as a designer and illustrator for clients such as the Canadian Wildlife Service, The Montreal Museum of Fine Arts, Canada Post and Caisse de dépôt et placements du Québec. In 1976, she joined the Graphic Design Department as a part-time teacher but continued to work as a graphic Designer and Illustrator. In 1980, she became full-time at Dawson and served two terms as the Chairperson of the Graphic Design department. With Roy Carter, she co-wrote the revised Graphic Design Program. Susan has won a number of design awards and has been published several times in Grafika, Applied Arts and Graphis. She has been a member of design juries at Concordia University and Grafika. In 2009, Susan retired from full-time teaching to set up design514 and to work as a book and stamp designer. She continues to teach illustration and poster design as a part-time teacher at Dawson. Her work can be seen on www.design514.com.

vfeshchenko.bio: Volodymyr Feshcenko graduated from Kiev State University in the Ukraine (Ph.D. 1987). He worked as an optoelectronic engineer and researcher in the fields of fibre-optic temperature sensors, semiconductor laser technology and satellite system software. Volodymyr has been teaching since 1997 in both physics (Dawson) and telecommunications (Institut Superieur d’Electronique).
